title: Music compositions
text:
This is my first composition, a piece for solo piano that is a “musical metaphor” to the Cantor function, also known as a devil’s staircase, for its “infinite” number of steps. Apart from using several ideas from the iterative process of the construction of the Cantor set, the main goal of the piece is to evoke the feeling of anguish when climbing an infinite staircase.
Regarding the name of the piece, Arnediad Dim means “endless staircase” in Sindarin, a fictional language created by J. R. R. Tolkien, and in his works, it is the most spoken language by the elves of the Third Age in Middle-earth, the time and place in which the events of The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings take place. The analogy is due to two crucial moments in The Lord of the Rings where the characters went through long and dangerous staircases: the battle of the wizard Gandalf with a Balrog, whose final part took place on the long circular staircase that goes from the depths of the Mines of Moria to the top of the mountain of Zirakzigil; and the arrival of Frodo, Sam, and Sméagol at the pass of Cirith Ungol, which occurs through a long and dark staircase that starts from the vicinity of the dangerous city of Minas Morgul.
Arnediad Dim was premiered at the VII International MusMat Conference, by pianist Tamara Ujakova:


The piece was also performed live, also by Tamara, on the XXX Panorama da Música Brasileira Atual, one of the most important events of contemporary concert music in Brazil:

text: Aos poucos estou disponibilizando meus materiais didáticos em minha página do GitHub. Aos poucos irei atualizando e colocando de outras matérias que oferto regularmente, pois o processo de organizar tudo que já tenho preparado é trabalhoso. title: Variational Inference for Dummies, part 1
text:
Introduction
Variational Inference (VI) is a tool for performing approximate inference on complex statistical models that is being even more widespread within the Statistics community, as well as in its applications. However, there is a lack in the literature for a comprehensive introduction to VI, including a background on Information Theory. This set of notes aim to fill this gap, as well as present an extensive (but potentially not exhaustive) overview of VI.

Inferência Variacional na moral, parte 1
text:
Introdução
Este conjunto de notas está no plano das ideias há bastante tempo, mais ou menos desde quando comecei a me aventurar no reino da Inferência Variacional (doravante IV), lá pelos anos de 2019, junto com meu grande amigo Carlos Tadeu. Resumidamente, IV é uma ferramenta para realizar inferência aproximada em modelos estatísticos demasiadamente complexos de modo que algoritmos de Monte Carlo baseados em cadeias de Markov (MCMC - Markov Chain Monte Carlo) são extremamente custosos computacionalmente, chegando possivelmente a serem inviáveis. Nos últimos anos, técnicas de IV estão cada vez mais difundidas na literatura estatística, e é justamente aí que nasce minha motivação para essas notas: por mais que tenhamos excelentes textos sobre o tema (veja por exemplo Hoffman et al. (2013), Kucukelbir et al. (2017), Blei, Kucukelbir, and McAuliffe (2017))
